name: Lake Wapello State Park

name: Ledges State Park

name: Lower Gar State Recreation Area

name: McIntosh Woods State Park

name: Mini-Wakan State Park

name: Pikes Point State Park

name: Pine Lake State Park

name: Park name
notes: Remarks

name: Afton State Park
notes: Lies on a glacial moraine with deep ravines that drop 300 feet (91 m) down to the St. Croix River.[9]

name: Banning State Park
notes: Contains 1.5 miles (2.4 km) of whitewater rapids and the remains of a historic quarry operation.[10]

name: Bear Head Lake State Park
notes: Provides road access and modern camping facilities in an environment similar to the nearby Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness.[11]

name: Beaver Creek Valley State Park
notes: Showcases the rugged topography of the Driftless Area in a narrow valley carved by a trout stream.[12]

name: Big Bog State Recreation Area
notes: Encompasses part of the largest peatland in the Lower 48 states (a National Natural Landmark) and a prime walleye fishery.[13]

name: Big Stone Lake State Park
notes: Protects two sections of shoreline on Big Stone Lake, the source of the Minnesota River.[14]

name: Blue Mounds State Park
notes: Protects an escarpment of Sioux Quartzite and Minnesota's only public bison herd.[15] A district of WPA structures is on the NRHP.[16]

name: Buffalo River State Park
notes: Preserves part of one of the state's largest and best tallgrass prairies.[17] A district of WPA structures is on the NRHP.[18]

name: Camden State Park
notes: Preserves a forested river valley in the midst of prairie and farm country.[19] A district of VCC and WPA structures is on the NRHP.[20]

name: Carley State Park
notes: Donated by State Senator James A. Carley to protect a stand of white pines. Used as an overflow campground for nearby Whitewater State Park.[21]

name: Cascade River State Park
notes: Stretches along 10.5 miles (16.9 km) of Lake Superior coastline in land rehabilitated after construction of Minnesota State Highway 61.[22] A WPA highway wayside is on the NRHP.[6]

name: Charles A. Lindbergh State Park
notes: Contains the restored home of Congressman Charles August Lindbergh and his son Charles Lindbergh, the famous aviator.[23] The house is a National Historic Landmark, and a district of WPA structures is on the NRHP.[24]

name: Crow Wing State Park
notes: Interprets the site of Old Crow Wing, an important town and trading center in the mid-19th century. The town site and a section of the Red River Trails are both on the NRHP.[6][25]

name: Cuyuna Country State Recreation Area
notes: In development as the land is rehabilitated from open-pit iron mining. Includes Portsmouth Mine Pit Lake, the state's deepest lake.[26]

name: Father Hennepin State Park
notes: Provides lakeside recreation in the region visited by Father Louis Hennepin during a French expedition in 1680.[27]

name: Flandrau State Park
notes: Created to provide water recreation near New Ulm.[28] Entire park is a district of CCC and WPA structures on the NRHP.[29]

name: Forestville/Mystery Cave State Park
notes: Encompasses the historic townsite of Forestville, the state's longest explored cave, and three blue-ribbon trout streams.[30]

name: Fort Ridgely State Park
notes: Surrounds Fort Ridgely, site of the Battle of Fort Ridgely during the Dakota War of 1862. The fort and a large district of CCC structures are both on the NRHP.[31][32]

name: Fort Snelling State Park
notes: Contains historic Fort Snelling, built in 1819, and floodplain forest in the heart of Minneapolis – Saint Paul. The fort is a National Historic Landmark and the entire park is part of the Mississippi National River and Recreation Area.[33]

name: Franz Jevne State Park
notes: Features scenic property on the Canada–United States border, donated by the sons of Franz Jevne, a lawyer, on the condition that the park be named after their father.[34]

name: Frontenac State Park
notes: Attracts 260 species of year-round and migrant birds with its variety of habitats. Includes a natural arch atop a 430-foot (130 m) bluff.[35]

name: Garden Island State Recreation Area
notes: Comprises a nearly undeveloped island, 15 mi (24 km) from the closest mainland marinas, that once bore Native American gardens.[36]

name: George H. Crosby Manitou State Park
notes: Contains undeveloped North Woods wilderness geared towards backpackers.[37]

name: Glacial Lakes State Park
notes: Preserves rolling tallgrass prairie amidst the glacial landforms of the Leaf Hills Moraines.[38]

name: Glendalough State Park
notes: Developed from the former private retreat and game farm of the owners of the Star Tribune newspaper, with a heritage fishery of large game fish.[39]

name: Gooseberry Falls State Park
notes: Serves as the gateway to the scenic North Shore. Features five waterfalls, an agate beach, and a large district of CCC structures on the NRHP.[40][41]

name: Grand Portage State Park
notes: Features a 120-foot (37 m) waterfall, Minnesota's tallest, on the Canada–United States border. Co-managed with the Grand Portage Indian Reservation, the only state – tribal collaboration of a U.S. state park.[42]

name: Great River Bluffs State Park
notes: Features 500-foot-high (150 m) bluffs and steep goat prairies. Formerly named O.L. Kipp State Park.[44]

name: Greenleaf Lake State Recreation Area
notes: In development and open for limited day-use recreation.[45]

name: Hayes Lake State Park
notes: Provides fishing and swimming opportunities in an exclusively recreational reservoir free of agricultural runoff or water level fluctuations for irrigation or power generation.[4]:250

name: Hill-Annex Mine State Park
notes: Offers tours of a former open-pit iron mine and fossil collecting. A district of mine structures is on the NRHP.[46]

name: Interstate State Park
notes: Created in conjunction with a state park in Wisconsin to protect a basalt gorge and glacial potholes.[47] Two districts of CCC and WPA structures are on the NRHP.[48]

name: Iron Range Off-Highway Vehicle State Recreation Area
notes: Provides 36 miles (58 km) of trails for off highway vehicles.[49]

name: Itasca State Park
notes: Minnesota's oldest state park, which preserves the headwaters of the Mississippi River. The entire park and an individual archaeological site are on the NRHP, and a subsection is a National Natural Landmark.[50]

name: Jay Cooke State Park
notes: Showcases a rocky, whitewater-strewn river churning through the North Woods.[51] Three districts of CCC and WPA structures and a long-used portage route are on the NRHP.[52]

name: John A. Latsch State Park
notes: Features three steep river bluffs.[53]

name: Judge C. R. Magney State Park
notes: Contains the geologically unexplained Devil's Kettle, a large glacial kettle into which half of the Brule River disappears.[54]

name: Kilen Woods State Park
notes: Preserves a riverside parcel of forested hills on the Coteau des Prairies.[55]

name: La Salle Lake State Recreation Area
notes: In development around the second-deepest lake in Minnesota.[56]

name: Lac qui Parle State Park
notes: Attracts thousands of migrating waterfowl, earning it the name "Lake that Speaks."[57] A district of WPA buildings is on the NRHP.[58]

name: Lake Bemidji State Park
notes: Features a recreational lakeshore and a spruce-tamarack bog.[59] A district of CCC and National Youth Administration structures is on the NRHP.[60]

name: Lake Bronson State Park
notes: Features a reservoir created during a drought in the 1930s. A district of WPA structures is on the NRHP.[61]

name: Lake Carlos State Park
notes: Preserves diverse habitats from prairie to hardwood forest to tamarack bog in a transition zone.[62] Two districts of WPA structures are on the NRHP.[63]

name: Lake Louise State Park
notes: Features a reservoir surrounded by oak savanna and patches of hardwood forest. Minnesota's oldest continuous recreation area, formerly a town park since the 1860s.[64]

name: Lake Maria State Park
notes: Provides a lightly developed wilderness area near Minneapolis – Saint Paul in a morainal landscape of Big Woods.[65]

name: Lake Shetek State Park
notes: Features remnants of pioneer history around the largest lake in southwestern Minnesota.[66] Two districts of WPA structures are on the NRHP.[67]

name: Lake Vermilion State Park
notes: Recently purchased and in development on the fifth-largest lake in Minnesota.[68]

name: Maplewood State Park
notes: Preserves a forest/prairie transition zone in the Leaf Hills Moraines.[69] A Native American archaeological site is on the NRHP.

name: McCarthy Beach State Park
notes: Features a .5-mile-long (0.80 km) beach on an isthmus between two lakes.[70]

name: Mille Lacs Kathio State Park
notes: Preserves 19 identified archaeological sites dating back 9000 years. The entire park is a National Historic Landmark and four sites are individually listed on the NRHP.[6][71]

name: Minneopa State Park
notes: Showcases the largest waterfall in southern Minnesota. The 1864 Seppman Mill and a district of WPA structures are each on the NRHP.[72]

name: Minnesota Valley State Recreation Area
notes: Comprises non-contiguous sections interspersed with units of the Minnesota Valley National Wildlife Refuge in the valley formed by Glacial River Warren.[73]

name: Monson Lake State Park
notes: Established as a memorial to settlers who died in the Dakota War of 1862.[74] A district of CCC and WPA structures is on the NRHP.[75]

name: Moose Lake State Park
notes: Provides water recreation and an exhibit hall on Lake Superior agates (the state gemstone) and the geology of Minnesota.[76]

name: Myre-Big Island State Park
notes: Features two islands with old growth hardwood forest since they were out of reach of prairie fires. Also houses one of the state's largest research collections of Native American artifacts.[77]

name: Nerstrand-Big Woods State Park
notes: Preserves a remnant stand of Big Woods.[78]

name: Old Mill State Park
notes: Features two mills and a log cabin from the late 19th Century.[79] The Larson Mill and a district of WPA structures are each on the NRHP.[80]

name: Red River State Recreation Area
notes: Reclaims land devastated by the 1997 Red River Flood as part of the Greater Grand Forks Greenway, which serves the dual purpose of holding back river waters during floods and providing recreational opportunities.[81]

name: Rice Lake State Park
notes: Surrounds a shallow lake which attracts migrating waterfowl.[82]

name: St. Croix Islands State Recreation Area
notes: Comprises five islands near the St. Croix Boom Site that came under state control but were never developed. Leased to the Saint Croix National Scenic Riverway.[4]:318

name: St. Croix State Park
notes: Developed as a Recreational Demonstration Area by the CCC and the WPA to repurpose land too poor to farm. The entire park is a National Historic Landmark.[83]

name: Sakatah Lake State Park
notes: Features a transitional zone between prairie and Big Woods on a natural widening of the Cannon River.[84]

name: Savanna Portage State Park
notes: Preserves a historically important and legendarily difficult 6-mile (9.7 km) portage over a continental divide between the watersheds of the Mississippi River and Lake Superior.[85] The portage is on the NRHP.[6]

name: Scenic State Park
notes: Features pristine lakes and old-growth pines. Two districts of structures built by the first CCC state park camp in Minnesota are on the NRHP.[86]

name: Schoolcraft State Park
notes: Honors Henry Schoolcraft, who charted the origins of the Mississippi River with the Ojibwe guide Ozawindib. Preserves virgin pine forest that includes a white pine over 300 years old.[87]

name: Sibley State Park
notes: Honors Henry Hastings Sibley, the first governor of Minnesota, with a popular recreational lakeshore and a morainal landscape.[88] A district of CCC structures is on the NRHP.[89]

name: Soudan Underground Mine State Park
notes: Offers tours of Minnesota's oldest, deepest, and richest iron mine and a modern high energy physics laboratory. The mine is a National Historic Landmark[90] and a row of 20th Century boathouses is on the NRHP.

name: Split Rock Creek State Park
notes: Features a recreational reservoir on the Coteau des Prairies.[91]

name: Split Rock Lighthouse State Park
notes: Surrounds the clifftop Split Rock Lighthouse, one of the most photographed lighthouses in the United States.[92] The lighthouse is a National Historic Landmark.

name: Temperance River State Park
notes: Showcases the deep, narrow gorge of the Temperance River (so named for its lack of a "bar" at its mouth) and Carlton Peak, a rock climbing area.[93]

name: Tettegouche State Park
notes: Encompasses the tallest waterfall within the state's borders, the iconic headlands of Palisade Head and Shovel Point, and a historic fishing camp which is on the NRHP.[94]

name: Upper Sioux Agency State Park
notes: Interprets the site of the agency that administered a Dakota Indian reservation until it was destroyed during the Dakota War of 1862.[95] The agency is on the NRHP.[6]

name: Whitewater State Park
notes: Showcases a popular steep-sided river valley in the Driftless Area.[96] A large district of CCC and WPA structures is on the NRHP.[97]

name: Wild River State Park
notes: Follows 18 miles (29 km) of one of the first waterways designated a National Wild and Scenic River.[98] A section of the Point Douglas to Superior Military Road is on the NRHP.[99]

name: William O'Brien State Park
notes: Provides outdoor recreation opportunities near Minneapolis – Saint Paul.[100]

name: Zippel Bay State Park
notes: Provides water recreation and birdwatching opportunities on the shore of the country's sixth largest lake.[101]

name: Buccaneer State Park
notes: Waterpark, camping

name: Clark Creek Natural Area
notes: Fifty waterfalls

notes: Boating, fishing, camping

name: Florewood State Park
notes: Leased by Leflore County; "temporarily closed" since auction of artifacts and buildings in 2005

name: Beaver Dam State Park
notes: Preserves a section of Beaver Dam Wash in eastern Nevada's most remote state park.

name: Berlin–Ichthyosaur State Park
notes: Preserves in situ ichthyosaur fossils and the ghost town of Berlin.

name: Big Bend of the Colorado State Recreation Area
notes: Overlooks the Colorado River within the town limits of Laughlin.

name: Cathedral Gorge State Park
notes: Showcases a gorge with soft bentonite walls eroded into dramatic spires.

name: Cave Lake State Park
notes: Features a 32-acre (13 ha) reservoir in the northern Schell Creek Range.

name: Dayton State Park
notes: Features a stretch of the Carson River and the site of an 1861 mill built to process silver ore from the Comstock Lode.

name: Echo Canyon State Park
notes: Adjoins a 65-acre (26 ha) reservoir.

name: Elgin Schoolhouse State Historic Site
notes: Preserves a rural schoolhouse used from 1922–1967. Closed since 2008 due to unrepaired flood damage on Nevada State Route 317.

name: Fort Churchill State Historic Park
notes: Encompasses the ruins of a U.S. Army fort staffed 1860–1869, plus a waystation on the Pony Express and Central Overland Routes, and a corridor along the Carson River connecting to Lahontan State Recreation Area.

name: Kershaw–Ryan State Park
notes: Features a verdant canyon first homesteaded in 1873.

name: Lahontan State Recreation Area
notes: Surrounds Lake Lahontan, a 10,000-acre (4,000 ha) reservoir on the Carson River.

name: Lake Tahoe – Nevada State Park
notes: Comprises six units on the northeastern shore of Lake Tahoe and its backcountry.

name: Mormon Station State Historic Park
notes: Interprets Nevada's first permanent nonnative settlement, established in 1851 on the California Trail by Mormon pioneers.

name: Old Las Vegas Mormon Fort State Historic Park
notes: Interprets a partially reconstructed fort built by Mormon missionaries in 1855, the first nonnative structure in what would become Las Vegas.

name: Rye Patch State Recreation Area
notes: Adjoins the 11,000-acre (4,500 ha) Rye Patch Reservoir on the Humboldt River.

name: South Fork State Recreation Area
notes: Surrounds the 1,650-acre (670 ha) South Fork Reservoir on the South Fork Humboldt River.

name: Spring Mountain Ranch State Park
notes: Preserves the historic Sandstone Ranch established in 1876.

name: Spring Valley State Park
notes: Adjoins the 65-acre (26 ha) Eagle Valley Reservoir.

name: Valley of Fire State Park
notes: Showcases red sandstone formations in Nevada's oldest and largest state park.

name: Van Sickle Bi-State Park
notes: Managed by the Nevada Division of State Parks in conjunction with the California Tahoe Conservancy; 575 acres lie within Nevada while 150 are within El Dorado County, California.

name: Ward Charcoal Ovens State Historic Park
notes: Preserves six 30-foot-high (9.1 m) charcoal ovens used from 1876–1879 to produce fuel for smelting silver ore.

name: Washoe Lake State Park
notes: Provides recreation opportunities on Washoe Lake, between Carson City and Reno.

name: Wild Horse State Recreation Area
notes: Provides water recreation on the northeast shore of 2,830-acre (1,150 ha) Wild Horse Reservoir on the Owyhee River.

notes: NA

name: White Lake State Park
notes: NA

name: Winslow State Park
notes: NA

name: Allaire State Park
notes: Features restored nineteenth-century ironworks, Allaire Village; ecosystem and geography of New Jersey's coastal plains region and Manasquan River floodplain—habitat for over 200 species of wildflowers, trees and plants, and birds; includes high-iron and acidic podzolic soils and bog iron deposits. Hosts the Pine Creek Railroad, an excursion rail line operated by the New Jersey Museum of Transportation.

name: Allamuchy Mountain State Park
notes: Located along Allamuchy Mountain and Musconetcong River, features 2,440-acre (9.9 km2) Allamuchy Natural Area of mature mixed oak-hardwood forests, natural fields; 14 miles of marked and 20 miles of unmarked trails including Sussex Branch Trail and Highlands Trail; Waterloo Village a restored eighteenth- and nineteenth-century village associated with the iron industry and Morris Canal.

name: Barnegat Lighthouse State Park
county: At the northern tip of Long Beach Island in Ocean County39°45′46.91″N 74°06′28.74″W﻿ / ﻿39.7630306°N 74.1079833°W﻿ / 39.7630306 county
notes: The site of Barnegat Lighthouse (1859); offers marine birdwatching and saltwater fishing, located along on New Jersey Coastal Heritage Trail Route.

name: Cape May Point State Park
county: Lower Township in Cape May County38°56′05″N 74°57′33″W﻿ / ﻿38.934810°N 74.959202°W﻿ / 38.934810 county
notes: The site of Cape May Lighthouse (1859); premier location in North America for observing fall bird migration to the south.

name: Capital State Park
notes: Park currently being developed, includes buildings and areas of Trenton's capitol complex, waterfront areas along Delaware River and Assunpink Creek; celebrate Trenton’s Native American, Colonial, Revolutionary War, ethnic, and industrial heritage

name: Cheesequake State Park
notes: Transitional zone between two different ecosystems featuring open fields, saltwater and freshwater marshes, Pine Barrens white cedar swamp, and northeastern hardwood forest.

name: Corson's Inlet State Park
county: Corson's Inlet between Ocean City county
notes: One of the last undeveloped tracts along the state’s oceanfront; features primary and secondary sand dune systems, shoreline overwash, marine estuaries; migratory and residential wildlife species; hiking, fishing, crabbing, boating and sunbathing.

name: Delaware and Raritan Canal State Park
county: Over 60 linear miles through Central New Jersey in Middlesex county
notes: Delaware and Raritan Canal mileage including the 36-mile (58 km) main canal between New Brunswick and Trenton and 22-mile (35 km) feeder canal between Trenton and Frenchtown; many historic structures including buildings, locks, spillways, and towpath; described as "the longest (and narrowest) recreation area in the state. A greenway that snakes through one of the most heavily populated regions in the world."

name: Double Trouble State Park
notes: Provides "a window into the Pine Barrens history" and region's ecosystem; preserved historic village associated with New Jersey cranberry agriculture and Atlantic White Cedar logging and milling industries.

name: Edison State Park
notes: The site consists of a two-room museum with interpretative and interactive exhibits about Thomas A. Edison's Menlo Park laboratory and the Edison Memorial Tower

name: Farny State Park
notes: Adjacent to Split Rock Reservoir; features mature mixed oak hardwood forest, swamps, and streams characteristic of the Highlands physiographic province; provides habitat for the endangered red-shouldered hawk and threatened barred owl.

name: Fort Mott State Park
county: Pennsville Township in Salem County39°36′24″N 75°33′06″W﻿ / ﻿39.6066°N 75.5516°W﻿ / 39.6066 county
notes: Coastal defense battery built 1872–1902 to protect the Delaware River and Philadelphia after the American Civil War. Troops were stationed at site from 1897 to 1922.

name: Hacklebarney State Park
notes: The glacial valley and gorge of the Black River; features the rock strewn landscape of the glacial moraine from the Wisconsinan glaciation; features three endangered species: American ginseng, leatherwood and Virginia pennywort

name: High Point State Park
notes: Donated by Colonel Anthony R. Kuser and wife Susie Dryden Kuser; landscaping designed by the Olmsted Brothers of Boston, sons of Frederick Law Olmsted, designer of New York City's Central Park. Features the highest elevation in New Jersey, High Point, a 1,803-foot (550 m) prominence of Kittatinny Mountain marked by a 220-foot (67 m) granite obelisk erected as veterans memorial.

name: Hopatcong State Park
notes: Two separate parcels of land, one on the southwestern shore of state's largest freshwater lake, Lake Hopatcong, another on Lake Musconetcong; the park features remnants of the Morris Canal and Lake Hopatcong Historical Museum.

name: Island Beach State Park
county: Former borough of Island Beach county
notes: Island Beach is a narrow 10-mile (16 km) barrier island between Atlantic Ocean and Barnegat Bay featuring untouched primary dunes, thicket, freshwater wetlands, maritime forest and tidal marshes; also New Jersey's largest osprey colony, peregrine falcons, wading birds, shorebirds, waterfowl, and migrating songbirds.

name: Kittatinny Valley State Park
notes: Features glacial lakes and limestone outcroppings at the headwaters of the Pequest River; part of the Sussex Branch Trail passes through park; site of the Aeroflex–Andover Airport, a New Jersey Forest Fire Service airbase for aerial wildfire suppression.

name: Liberty State Park
county: Jersey City in Hudson County40°42′15″N 74°02′57″W﻿ / ﻿40.70417°N 74.04917°W﻿ / 40.70417 county
notes: Created to commemorate country's bicentennial celebration, features Central Railroad of New Jersey Terminal (CRRNJ); sweeping view of the Hudson River and Manhattan skyline; Liberty Science Center; "Empty Sky" Memorial for the September 11 terrorist attacks; ferry service to Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty.

name: Long Pond Ironworks State Park
notes: Features Monksville Reservoir and ruins of Long Pond Ironworks, an eighteenth- and nineteenth-century ironworking community (1766–1882) along the Wanaque River.

name: Monmouth Battlefield State Park
notes: Site of the June 28, 1778 Battle of Monmouth during the American Revolution. George Washington and Continental Army attacked the rear of a British Army column commanded by Lieutenant General Sir Henry Clinton; features interpretative center, annual reenactment battle held in June, the Craig House (1746), the Rhea-Applegate house (1745), and a pick-your-own fruit orchard.

name: Parvin State Park
county: Pittsgrove Township in Salem County39°30′42″N 75°08′18″W﻿ / ﻿39.511803°N 75.138204°W﻿ / 39.511803 county
notes: Features Pine Barrens swamp hardwood and pine forest ecosystem along Muddy Run (Maurice River tributary). Features over 200 flowering plant species including blossoming dogwood, laurel, holly, magnolia, wild azalea. Historically, the home of a CCC camp (1933–1941), summer displacement camp for Japanese-American children during World War II; prisoner-of-war camp for German soldiers, and housing for Kalmyk refugees who escaped Eastern Europe and the USSR in 1952.

name: Pigeon Swamp State Park
county: South Brunswick Township in Middlesex County40°23′13″N 74°28′26″W﻿ / ﻿40.38689°N 74.47383°W﻿ / 40.38689 county
notes: Located in the watershed of Lawrence Brook, an undeveloped park featuring open ponds and hardwood forests that were a major nesting site for the now-extinct passenger pigeon.

name: Princeton Battlefield State Park
county: Princeton Borough in Mercer County40°19′45″N 74°40′36″W﻿ / ﻿40.32917°N 74.67667°W﻿ / 40.32917 county
notes: Site of the Battle of Princeton fought between British and American on January 3, 1777—an victory that proved decisive in restoring American morale during American Revolution. Includes the Clarke House where General Hugh Mercer died from his wounds nine days later despite the efforts of Dr Benjamin Rush.

name: Rancocas State Park
county: Westampton Township in Burlington County40°00′27.13″N 74°49′59.59″W﻿ / ﻿40.0075361°N 74.8332194°W﻿ / 40.0075361 county
notes: Located along the North Branch of the Rancocas Creek and an extensive freshwater tidal marsh.

name: Ringwood State Park
notes: Located on Ramapo Mountain, features historic Ringwood Manor, New Jersey Botanical Garden at Skylands Manor, and Shepherd Lake Recreation Area.

name: Stephens State Park
notes: Located along Musconetcong River, features remnants of one of 23 locks and section of towpath of the Morris Canal. Highlands Trail runs through the park.

name: Swartswood State Park
notes: New Jersey's first state park. The focus of the park was a place for recreation at the state's third-largest freshwater lake, Swartswood Lake (a glacial lake).

name: Voorhees State Park
notes: Former New Jersey governor Foster M. Voorhees created the park with donation of his 325-acre (1.32 km2) farm; scenic views of Round Valley Reservoir and Spruce Run Reservoir; an observatory and astronomy education center, operated by the New Jersey Astronomical Association, offers the largest working telescope accessible to the public in the state—a 26-inch Cassegrain reflector.

name: Washington Crossing State Park
notes: Commemorates site where General George Washington and Continental Army crossed the ice-clogged Delaware River on December 25, 1776, before the Battle of Trenton and Battle of Princeton during the American Revolution.

name: Washington Rock State Park
notes: Site of a lookout used by George Washington in 1777 monitor British troop movements around New York City and northern New Jersey when the Continental Army was stationed at the Middlebrook encampment.

name: Wawayanda State Park
notes: Wawayanda offers 60 miles (97 km) of trails including a 20-mile (32 km) segment of the Appalachian Trail. Features 1,325-acre (5.36 km2) Bearfort Mountain Natural Area, 399-acre (1.61 km2) Wawayanda Hemlock Ravine Natural Area (399 acres), and 2,167-acre (8.77 km2) Wawayanda Swamp Natural Area

name: Park name
notes: m

name: Bluewater Lake State Park
notes: Encircles a 1,200-acre (490 ha) reservoir in the Zuni Mountains.[6]

name: Bottomless Lakes State Park
notes: Encompasses eight cenotes whose greenish-blue water disguises their true depth.[7]

name: Brantley Lake State Park
notes: Features New Mexico's southernmost lake, a 4,000-acre (1,600 ha) reservoir on the Pecos River.[8]

name: Caballo Lake State Park
notes: Surrounds Caballo Lake, a 11,500-acre (4,700 ha) reservoir on the Rio Grande.[9]

name: Cerrillos Hills State Park
notes: Provides day-use recreation amidst 1,100 years of mining history.[10]

name: Cimarron Canyon State Park
notes: Showcases the canyon of the Cimarron River and the Palisades Sill formation.[11]

name: City of Rocks State Park
notes: Features rock formations eroded out of 35-million-year-old volcanic ash, and a public observatory.[12]

name: Clayton Lake State Park
notes: Features a 170-acre (69 ha) reservoir and an extensive fossil trackway of dinosaur footprints.[13]

name: Conchas Lake State Park
notes: Adjoins a 16,400-acre (6,600 ha) reservoir on the Canadian River.[15]

name: Coyote Creek State Park
notes: Boasts the most densely stocked trout stream in New Mexico.[16]

name: Eagle Nest Lake State Park
notes: Provides access to a 2,400-acre (970 ha) reservoir in a scenic mountain valley.[17]

name: Elephant Butte Lake State Park
notes: Surrounds Elephant Butte Reservoir, the state's largest and most popular reservoir.[18]

name: El Vado Lake State Park
notes: Provides access to a 3,200-acre (1,300 ha) reservoir adjacent to Heron Lake State Park.[19]

name: Fenton Lake State Park
notes: Encompasses a 37-acre (15 ha) reservoir surrounded by ponderosa pine forest.[20]

name: Heron Lake State Park
notes: Provides access to a 5,900-acre (2,400 ha) no-wake reservoir adjacent to El Vado Lake State Park.[21]

name: Hyde Memorial State Park
notes: Provides outdoor recreation amenities near Santa Fe.[22]

name: Leasburg Dam State Park
notes: Features a quiet stretch of the Rio Grande below a 1908 diversion dam.[23]

name: Living Desert Zoo and Gardens State Park
notes: Comprises a zoo and botanical garden of wildlife native to the Chihuahuan Desert in the city of Carlsbad.[24]

name: Manzano Mountains State Park
notes: Protects part of the forested foothills of the Manzano Mountains.[25]

name: Mesilla Valley Bosque State Park
notes: Interprets a bosque on the Rio Grande and adjacent Chihuahuan Desert.[26]

name: Morphy Lake State Park
notes: Preserves a small, secluded lake in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains.[27]

name: Navajo Lake State Park
notes: Comprises three units on New Mexico's second-largest reservoir.[28]

name: Oasis State Park
notes: Features a fishing pond and sand dunes amidst the east-central plains.[29]

name: Oliver Lee Memorial State Park
notes: Showcases a verdant canyon in the Sacramento Mountains and Oliver Lee's restored 1893 ranch house.[30]

name: Pancho Villa State Park
notes: Interprets the 1916 Battle of Columbus (Pancho Villa's raid onto U.S. soil) and the retaliatory Pancho Villa Expedition.[31]

name: Percha Dam State Park
notes: Provides outdoor recreation on an impounded section of the Rio Grande.[32]

name: Rio Grande Nature Center State Park
notes: Interprets a bosque on the Rio Grande in Albuquerque.[33]

name: Rockhound State Park
notes: Allows mineral collecting for amateur geology in the Florida Mountains.[34]

name: Santa Rosa Lake State Park
notes: Adjoins a 3,800-acre (1,500 ha) reservoir.[35]

name: Storrie Lake State Park
notes: Adjoins a 1,100-acre (450 ha) reservoir in the Zuni Mountains.[36]

name: Sugarite Canyon State Park
notes: Interprets the ruins of a historic early-20th-century coal-mining camp.[37]

name: Sumner Lake State Park
notes: Adjoins a 4,500-acre (1,800 ha) reservoir on the Pecos River.[38]

name: Ute Lake State Park
notes: Adjoins an 8,200-acre (3,300 ha) reservoir on the Canadian River.[39]

name: Vietnam Veterans Memorial State Park
notes: Honors the veterans of the Vietnam War, the country's oldest such memorial (established 1968) and the only one comprising a whole state park.[40]

name: Villanueva State Park
notes: Preserves a red sandstone canyon on the Pecos River.[41]

name: Allan H. Treman State Marine Park
notes: Includes a marina with 430 boat slips, fishing, birdwatching, and picnic tables.[7]

name: Allegany State Park
notes: Largest state park in New York. Includes two separate areas developed for recreation, the Red House Area and the Quaker Area, each with cabins and campsites. Both areas include formally designated bird conservation areas.[8][9]

name: Amherst State Park
notes: Located on the grounds of a former Catholic convent. Operated by the Town of Amherst.[10]

name: Amsterdam Beach State Park
notes: Undeveloped except for trails. Operated in conjunction with the Town of East Hampton and Suffolk County.[11]

name: Battle Island State Park
notes: Includes the 18-hole Battle Island State Park Golf Course.[13] Named for a battle that took place nearby during the French and Indian War in 1756.[14]

name: Bayard Cutting Arboretum State Park
notes: Includes a large arboretum designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and the Westbrook mansion designed by Charles C. Haight.[15]

name: Bayswater Point State Park
notes: Undeveloped. Previously home to a large mansion, now destroyed.[17] Presently hosts passive recreation while preserving shorebird habitat.[18]

name: Bear Mountain State Park
notes: Managed in conjunction with the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.[20]

name: Beaver Island State Park
notes: Located on Grand Island. Includes a USGA-recognized championship 18-hole public golf course.[22]

name: Beechwood State Park
notes: Undeveloped. Previously the site of a Girl Scout camp. Managed by the Town of Sodus since 2010.[24]

name: Belmont Lake State Park
notes: Day-use only. Formerly hosted the headquarters of the Long Island State Park Commission.[25]

name: Bethpage State Park
notes: Includes five golf courses, including the Bethpage Black Course, which hosted the 2002 and 2009 U.S. Open Golf Championships.

name: Betty and Wilbur Davis State Park
notes: Features full-service cabins and trails through meadows and forest.[28]

name: Big Six Mile Creek Marina
notes: Functions as a marina with 134 seasonal boat slips and a boat launch ramp.[29]

name: Blauvelt State Park
notes: Undeveloped. Former location of Camp Bluefields, a rifle range used to train members of the New York National Guard prior to World War I. Managed in conjunction with the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.[30]

name: Bonavista State Park Golf Course
notes: Includes a nine-hole golf course.[31]

name: Bowman Lake State Park
notes: Features one of the largest campgrounds in central New York, containing 188 campsites for tents and trailers, as well as several rustic cabins.[33]

name: Braddock Bay State Park
notes: Popular birdwatching location; park is adjacent to the 2,125-acre (8.60 km2) Braddock Bay Fish and Wildlife Management Area.[34] Leased and maintained by the Town of Greece.[35]

name: Brentwood State Park
notes: An athletic field complex with eight soccer fields and two baseball fields on artificial turf.[37]

name: Bristol Beach State Park
notes: Undeveloped. Managed in conjunction with the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.[38]

name: Brookhaven State Park
notes: Protects a large area of the Long Island Pine Barrens and contains scattered wetlands.[39]

name: Buckhorn Island State Park
notes: Managed as a preserve with space for passive recreational uses such as biking, hiking and fishing. Includes a bird conservation area.[9][40]

name: Buffalo Harbor State Park
notes: Features a 1,000 slip marina and is part of an overall initiative to revitalize Buffalo's outer harbor.[43]

name: Burnham Point State Park
notes: Primarily offers space to camp, including 47 tent and trailer sites, 19 of which contain electrical hookups.[45]

name: Buttermilk Falls State Park
notes: Features several waterfalls and wooded gorges.[47]

name: Caleb Smith State Park Preserve
notes: Managed as a nature preserve.[48] Includes the Wyandanch Club Historic District.

name: Camp Hero State Park
notes: Occupies a portion of the former Montauk Air Force Station.[49]

name: Canandaigua Lake State Marine Park
notes: Offers boat launch facilities to allow access to Canandaigua Lake.

name: Canoe-Picnic Point State Park
notes: Accessible only by boat. Offers a campground with tent sites.[51]

name: Captree State Park
notes: Home to "The Captree Fleet", Long Island's largest public fleet of charter boats, available for fishing, scuba diving, sightseeing and excursion tours.[53][54]

name: Catharine Valley Trail
notes: Encompasses a planned 12-mile (19 km) recreation trail that follows abandoned railroad grades and canal towpaths between Watkins Glen and Horseheads.[56]

name: Caumsett State Historic Park Preserve
notes: Includes the former estate house of Marshall Field III, built in 1925 and among the largest of Long Island's Gold Coast Mansions; also includes a bird conservation area.[9]

name: Cayuga Lake State Park
notes: Offers amenities including a beach, boat launch, and a campground.[59]

name: Cedar Island State Park
notes: Accessible only by boat. Offers dockage, a day-use area and a small campground.[60]

name: Cedar Point State Park
notes: Includes a campground, beach, and boat launch.[61]

name: Chenango Valley State Park
notes: Offers a beach, campground, cabins, and 18-hole golf course.[62]

name: Cherry Plain State Park
notes: Offers a beach, fishing, and camping at 30 sites.[63] Located adjacent to the 4,153-acre (16.81 km2) Capital District Wildlife Management Area, which offers additional hiking and recreation.[64]

name: Chimney Bluffs State Park
notes: Features dramatically carved 150-foot-tall (46 m) shoreside cliffs formed from eroded drumlins.[65] Lightly developed for day-use only.

name: Chittenango Falls State Park
notes: Day-use only. Features a 167-foot (51 m) waterfall.[67] Also home to the endemic and endangered Chittenango ovate amber snail.[68]

name: Clarence Fahnestock State Park
notes: Includes the Taconic Outdoor Education Center. Offers a beach, fishing, and camping. Dedicated winter recreation facilities available seasonally.[69]

name: Clark Reservation State Park
notes: Centered around the former plunge pool of a large ice age-era waterfall. Harbors the largest U.S. population of the endangered American hart's tongue fern.[70]

name: Clay Pit Ponds State Park Preserve
notes: Managed as a nature preserve to protect wetlands, ponds, sand barrens, spring-fed streams, and forest on Staten Island. Includes a bird conservation area.[9][72]

name: Cold Spring Harbor State Park
notes: Day-use only. Comprises steep wooded slopes and intended to retain a natural character.[73] Allows passive recreation such as hiking, snowshoeing, and cross-country skiing.[74] Linked to Bethpage State Park by the linear Trail View State Park.[75]

name: Coles Creek State Park
notes: Offers a beach, marina, and a campground with 232 tent and trailer sites.[76]

name: Conesus Lake Boat Launch
notes: Offers a boat launch, fishing access, and picnic tables.[77]

name: Connetquot River State Park Preserve
notes: Home to the Long Island Environmental Interpretive Center. Managed to preserve wildlife habitat; allows for passive recreation such as hiking and fishing.[79]

name: Crab Island State Park
notes: Undeveloped. Obtained by New York State to prevent development of an historic site and cemetery associated with the War of 1812.[80]

name: Croil Island State Park
notes: Undeveloped. Maintained by the NYS Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation and owned by the New York Power Authority.[81]

name: Cumberland Bay State Park
notes: Offers a 2,700-foot (820 m) sand beach, playing fields, and a campground.[82]

name: Darien Lakes State Park
notes: Functions primarily as a campground, with additional features including a beach, fishing, and hiking trails.[83]

name: De Veaux Woods State Park
notes: Originally part of the campus for DeVeaux College for Orphans and Destitute Children, which closed in 1972. Includes recreational facilities and a parcel of old growth forest.[84]

name: Delta Lake State Park
notes: Offers a beach, boat launch, campground, and hiking.[86]

name: Devil's Hole State Park
notes: Overlooks the Niagara River gorge.

name: Dewolf Point State Park
notes: Located on Wellesley Island. Offers a boat launch, dock, and campsites.[87]

name: Donald J. Trump State Park
notes: Undeveloped. Land donated by and named for Donald Trump after development plans failed. Development and maintenance ceased in 2010.[88][89]

name: Earl W. Brydges Artpark State Park
notes: Serves as an exhibition space for outdoor sculpture,[90] as well as a concert venue.

notes: Day use only. Offers open space and views of the Manhattan skyline.[92]

notes: Offers a small campground, fishing, and trails.[93]

notes: Includes the Springbrook Greens State Golf Course[95]

notes: Undeveloped.

notes: Undeveloped.

notes: Includes the Jones Beach State Park Pitch and Putt Course[119]

name: Joseph Davis State Park
notes: Includes a bird conservation area.[9]

name: Bay Tree State Park

name: Carolina Beach State Park
notes: Named not for a beach, rather the Town of Carolina Beach, the park is located along the banks of the Cape Fear River and Snow's Cut (part of the Intracoastal Waterway). The park is best known for its variety of wild carnivorous plants, including the Venus Flytrap.

name: Carvers Creek State Park
notes:
Under development;
Interim facilities are open at the park's historic Long Valley Farm Access.

name: Chimney Rock State Park
notes:
Under development;
The park protects the landscape of Hickory Nut Gorge, including its most well known feature, Chimney Rock.

name: Cliffs of the Neuse State Park
notes: The park protects ancient cliff faces located along the banks of the Neuse River.

name: Crowders Mountain State Park
notes: The park protects the Kings Mountain Ridgeline in North Carolina, including its highest peaks Crowder's Mountain and King's Pinnacle. The park is also adjacent to Kings Mountain State Park in South Carolina, which in turn is adjacent to Kings Mountain National Military Park. All three parks are connected via the Kings Mountain Ridgeline Trail.

name: Dismal Swamp State Park
notes:
Under development;
The park protects large part of the Great Dismal Swamp, and it is adjacent to Great Dismal Swamp National Wildlife Refuge. It is bounded on the east by the Dismal Swamp Canal.

name: Elk Knob State Park
notes:
Under development;
The park preserves some of the highest peaks in Ashe and Watauga Counties, and it protects headwaters of the North Fork New River.

name: Eno River State Park
notes: The park protects the banks of the Eno River and surrounding lands.

name: Fort Macon State Park
notes: The first North Carolina State Park to open to the public. It protects the historic Fort Macon and the eastern end of Bogue Banks.

name: Goose Creek State Park
notes: The park protects part of the landscape along the Pamlico Sound.

name: Gorges State Park
notes:
Under development;
North Carolina's westernmost state park; it is located along the steep Blue Ridge Escarpment. The park is best known for the many waterfalls it provides access to, both inside the park and on adjacent public lands.

name: Grandfather Mountain State Park
notes:
Under development;
Adjacent to the Blue Ridge Parkway, the park protects the highest peak located along the Blue Ridge Escarpment. The park consists of lands formerly known as the "backcountry area" when it was privately owned nature preserve.

name: Hammocks Beach State Park
notes: While protecting a variety of maritime habitats, the park is most known for its four-mile (6.4 km) long barrier island, Bear Island. The park operates a passenger ferry service between the mainland and island in the warmer months.

name: Hanging Rock State Park
notes: The park encompasses the eastern end of the Sauratown Mountain range, including a geologic feature known as Hanging Rock.[6] It also protects a segment of the Dan River.

name: Haw River State Park
notes:
Under development;
This park preserves large wetlands along the Haw River.

name: Jockey's Ridge State Park
notes: The park protects the tallest sand dune system on the East Coast of the United States.

name: Jones Lake State Park
notes: The park surrounds Jones State Lake and Salters State Lake, both of which are largely undeveloped Carolina Bay lakes.

name: Lake James State Park
notes:
Under redevelopment;
Located near the base of Linville Gorge, the park encompasses large parts of the Lake James shoreline. In 2004, the park nearly octupled in size after a land deal with Crescent Resources.

name: Lake Norman State Park
notes: Formerly known as Duke Power State Park, most of this park consists of lands donated by Duke Power along the shores of Lake Norman, the largest manmade body of fresh water in North Carolina.

name: Lake Waccamaw State Park
notes: This park is along the shoreline of Lake Waccamaw, the largest natural Carolina Bay lake.[7]

name: Lumber River State Park
notes: The State Park with the greatest geographic expanse, it preserves the banks of the black water Lumber River, which is Wild and Scenic River and a State River.

name: Mayo River State Park
notes:
Under development;
This new, still growing park is located along the Mayo River.

name: Medoc Mountain State Park
notes: At 325 foot (99 m), Medoc Mountain isn't a true mountain but rather the remnant of a former mountain range which eroded long ago.[8] The park preserves the land around the Medoc, as well as the banks of nearby Little Fishing Creek.

name: Merchants Millpond State Park
notes: The park protects a unique, cypress filled millpond and the Lassiter Swamp.

name: Morrow Mountain State Park
notes: At 936 foot (285 m), Morrow Mountain is the fourth tallest peak of the Uwharrie Mountains,[9] and the park encompasses several peaks of the range, just west of the Yadkin / Pee Dee River.

name: Mount Mitchell State Park
notes: The first North Carolina State Park, it protects the summit of Mount Mitchell the highest point in the eastern United States.[1]

name: New River State Park
notes: This park preserves the landscape along the New River, which is Wild and Scenic River and a State River.

name: Pettigrew State Park
notes: The park protects the banks of Lake Phelps, the state's second largest natural lake, and the Scuppernong River.[10]

name: Pilot Mountain State Park
notes: The park encompasses the western end of the Sauratown Mountain range, including Pilot Mountain, as well as an island filled segment of the Yadkin River.[11]

name: Raven Rock State Park
notes: Located along both banks of the Cape Fear River, the park encompasses a rock outcropping where the river crosses the fall line.

name: Singletary Lake State Park
notes: The park surrounds Singletary Lake, which is a State Lake and a Carolina Bay lake. The park's facilities are usually reserved for registered group campers, but limited day use may be allowed while the camps are unoccupied.

name: South Mountains State Park
notes:
Under redevelopment;
The largest unit of the state park system, it encompasses a large part of the South Mountains range, which is a branch of the Blue Ridge Mountains.

name: Stone Mountain State Park
notes: Adjacent to the Blue Ridge Parkway, this large park's centerpiece is a granite dome named Stone Mountain.

name: William B. Umstead State Park
notes: This large, forested park is in the heart of the Research Triangle.

name: Beaver Lake State Park
notes: Boating, fishing, camping

name: Butte Saint Paul State Recreation Area
notes: Historic missionary site

name: Cross Ranch State Park
notes: Boating, canoeing, camping

name: Crow Flies High State Recreation Area
notes: Day-use area with scenic lake views

name: Doyle Memorial State Recreation Area
notes: Fishing, boating, camping

name: Fort Abraham Lincoln State Park
notes: Home to On-A-Slant Indian Village

name: Fort Ransom State Park
notes: Preserved homesteader farms

name: Fort Stevenson State Park
notes: Includes Fort Stevenson State Park Arboretum

name: Grahams Island State Park
notes: Last remaining unit of the four former Devils Lake State Parks

name: Icelandic State Park
notes: Includes the Gunlogson Arboretum Nature Preserve

name: Indian Hills State Recreation Area and Resort
notes: Operated by private leasee

name: Lake Metigoshe State Park
notes: Adjacent to Turtle Mountain Provincial Park, Manitoba

name: Lake Sakakawea State Park
notes: Adjacent to Garrison Dam

name: Lewis and Clark State Park
notes: Fishing, boating, camping

name: Little Metigoshe State Recreation Area
notes: Fishing

name: Little Missouri State Park
notes: Badlands

name: Pelican Point State Recreation Area
notes: Undeveloped day-use area

name: Pembina Gorge State Recreation Area
notes: 12-mile (19 km) loop trail for off-road vehicles

name: Sully Creek State Park
notes: Start of the Maah Daah Hey Trail

name: Turtle River State Park
notes: Outdoor learning center

name: Allegheny Islands State Park
notes: Three alluvial islands near Pittsburgh with no facilities, and accessible only by boat

name: Archbald Pothole State Park
notes: One of world's largest potholes, 38 ft (12 m) deep, largest diameter 42 feet (13 m) by 24 feet (7 m)

name: Bald Eagle State Park
notes: 1,730 acre (700 ha) U.S. Army Corps of Engineers reservoir named for Medal of Honor recipient

name: Beltzville State Park
notes: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers lake is 949 acres (384 ha) with 19.8 miles (31.9 km) of shoreline.

name: Bendigo State Park
notes: Only 20 acres (8.1 ha) developed, name a corruption of Abednego

name: Benjamin Rush State Park
notes: Site of one of the world's largest community gardens, otherwise undeveloped

name: Big Pocono State Park
notes: On Camelback Mountain, site of Camelback Ski Area and Waterpark

name: Big Spring State Forest Picnic Area
notes: Park has trail to partially completed railroad tunnel in Conococheague Mountain.

name: Black Moshannon State Park
notes: Park has bog with three carnivorous plant species and 17 orchid varieties.[f][g]

name: Blue Knob State Park
notes: This former Recreation Demonstration Area on the state's second highest mountain has Blue Knob All Seasons Resort (skiing).

name: Boyd Big Tree Preserve Conservation Area
notes: On Blue Mountain, one of three Conservation Areas, named for donor Alex Boyd

name: Buchanan's Birthplace State Park
notes: Stone pyramid marks the birthplace of James Buchanan, 15th President of the United States.

name: Bucktail State Park Natural Area
notes: Park, named for the Bucktail Regiment, is a 75-mile (121 km) undeveloped scenic drive on PA 120.

name: Caledonia State Park
notes: Park, named for Thaddeus Stevens' iron furnace, is home to summer stock Totem Pole Playhouse.

name: Canoe Creek State Park
notes: Home of largest nursery colony of little brown bats in the state.

name: Chapman State Park
notes: Trailhead for trail system in surrounding Allegheny National Forest

name: Cherry Springs State Park
notes: Park known for some of the clearest, darkest night skies in the state and eastern US.[f][g]

name: Clear Creek State Park
notes: Start of popular canoe trip on 10 miles (6 km) of Clarion River to Cook Forest State Park[g]

name: Codorus State Park
notes: Man-made lake is 1,275 acres (516 ha), named for former village of Marburg now flooded by it.

name: Colonel Denning State Park
notes: Park named for William Denning, an American Revolutionary War veteran who was never a colonel.

name: Colton Point State Park
notes: On west rim of the Pennsylvania Grand Canyon, 800 feet (244 m) deep here[d][f][g]

name: Cook Forest State Park
notes: National Natural Landmark, one of America's top-50 state parks (National Geographic Traveler)[d][f][g]

name: Cowans Gap State Park
notes: Site of French and Indian War road, pioneer homestead, lumbering, and CCC camp[g]

name: Delaware Canal State Park
notes: Park runs 60 miles (97 km) along Delaware Canal, the only 19th century U.S. towpath canal left continuously intact.[f][g]

name: Denton Hill State Park
notes: Site of Ski Denton resort, also open for summer mountain biking

name: Elk State Park
notes: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers lake is 1,160 acres (470 ha).

name: Erie Bluffs State Park
notes: Park has 1.0 mile (0.6 km) of lake coastline and bluffs 90 feet (27 m) tall, and is being developed.

name: Evansburg State Park
notes: Park has 18 hole Skippack Golf Course and many outdoor recreational opportunities.[g]

name: Fort Washington State Park
notes: George Washington camped here in the American Revolutionary War's Philadelphia campaign.

name: Fowlers Hollow State Park
notes: Trailhead for the trail system of the surrounding Tuscarora State Forest

name: Frances Slocum State Park
notes: Park named for a girl kidnapped by the Lenape who lived the rest of her life with the Miami in Indiana.

name: French Creek State Park
notes: Former Recreation Demonstration Area, adjacent to Hopewell Furnace National Historic Site[f][g]

name: Gifford Pinchot State Park
notes: Gifford Pinchot was a Pennsylvania governor, conservationist, and first US Forest Service Chief.

name: Gouldsboro State Park
notes: Park named for village named for Jay Gould, next to Tobyhanna Army Depot.

name: Greenwood Furnace State Park
notes: Includes ghost town of Greenwood, former ironworks and charcoal hearths[f][g]

name: Hickory Run State Park
notes: Former Recreation Demonstration Area with a large boulder field that is a National Natural Landmark.[d][f]

name: Hillman State Park
notes: Managed for hunting by the Pennsylvania Game Commission and largely undeveloped

name: Hills Creek State Park
notes: Land previously used as a pigment mine for the paint industry

name: Hyner Run State Park
notes: On the site of Civilian Conservation Corps Camp S-75-PA

name: Hyner View State Park
notes: Scenic view of the West Branch Susquehanna River and launching point for hang gliding[f]

name: Jacobsburg Environmental Education Center
notes: Park surrounds Jacobsburg National Historic District, where rifles were manufactured during the American Revolution.[g]

name: Jennings Environmental Education Center
notes: Park contains the only publicly protected relict prairie ecosystem in Pennsylvania, 20 acres (8.1 ha).[f]

name: Joseph E. Ibberson Conservation Area
notes: On Peters Mountain, one of three Conservation Areas, named for donor Joseph E. Ibberson

name: Kettle Creek State Park
notes: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers reservoir is 160 acres (65 ha), park has many recreational facilities built by CCC.

name: Keystone State Park
notes: Park is named for the Keystone Coal and Coke Company that once owned the land and created the lake.

name: Kings Gap Environmental Education and Training Center
notes: Training center for park rangers of the Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources

name: Kinzua Bridge State Park
notes: Had 1882 Historic Civil Engineering Landmark railway bridge, once the world's highest and longest, destroyed by a tornado in 2003.[f][g]

name: Kooser State Park
notes: Site of battles between Native American tribes, part of Whiskey Rebellion [g]

name: Lackawanna State Park
notes: On site of a Turn of the Century era community fair

name: Laurel Hill State Park
notes: Former Recreation Demonstration Area with the largest CCC architecture collection of any Pennsylvania state park[g]

name: Laurel Mountain State Park
notes: Opened in 1939 by Richard K. Mellon and Rolling Rock brewery as one of the state's first ski areas, donated to the state in 1964

name: Laurel Ridge State Park
notes: The park surrounds the 70 mile (113 km) long Laurel Highlands Hiking Trail.

name: Laurel Summit State Park
notes: Day use picnic area and trailhead, 2,739 feet (835 m) above sea level

name: Lehigh Gorge State Park
notes: The Lehigh Gorge Trail follows the river through the park for 26 miles (42 km).

name: Leonard Harrison State Park
notes: On east rim of the Pennsylvania Grand Canyon, 800 feet (244 m) deep here[d][f]

name: Linn Run State Park
notes: Once a barren wasteland, now a thriving second growth forest with an excellent trout stream[g]

name: Little Buffalo State Park
notes: Park named for the bison that are believed to have once roamed the ridge and valley region of Pennsylvania.[g]

name: Little Pine State Park
notes: Historians believe a Shawnee village and burial ground were just north of the park.

name: Locust Lake State Park
notes: In a thriving second growth forest on the side of Locust Mountain

name: Lyman Run State Park
notes: Site of a Prisoner of War Camp during World War II

name: Marsh Creek State Park
notes: The village of Milford Mills was flooded by the creation of the lake, last Project 70 / 500 park.[g]

name: Maurice K. Goddard State Park
notes: Park named for Maurice K. Goddard, who led the creation of 45 state parks in 24 years of service.

name: McCalls Dam State Park
notes: In a remote location on a dirt road betweenR. B. Winter State Park and Eastville.

name: McConnells Mill State Park
notes: Features a deep scenic gorge with a restored watermill and a covered bridge[d][f][g]

name: Memorial Lake State Park
notes: Surrounded by Fort Indiantown Gap, headquarters of the Pennsylvania National Guard

name: Milton State Park
notes: On an island in the river, destroyed by Hurricane Agnes in 1972 and rebuilt

name: Mont Alto State Park
notes: Pennsylvania's current oldest state park and first State Forest Park, former iron works

name: Moraine State Park
notes: Park served as the location of the 1973 and 1977 National Scout Jamborees.[f]

name: Mt. Pisgah State Park
notes: Lake named for renowned American composer Stephen Foster.

name: Nescopeck State Park
notes: One of the newest state parks in Pennsylvania

name: Neshaminy State Park
notes: Park, on an estuary, donated by descendant of James Logan, colonial secretary to William Penn

name: Nockamixon State Park
notes: Nockamixon means "place of soft soil" in the Lenape language.

name: Nolde Forest Environmental Education Center
notes: Once a forest privately owned by Jacob Nolde

name: Norristown Farm Park
notes: Managed by the Montgomery County Department of Parks

name: Ohiopyle State Park
notes: One of the most popular white-water rafting destinations on the East Coast[d][f]

name: Oil Creek State Park
notes: Edwin Drake drilled the first successful oil well in the world here in 1859.[f]

name: Ole Bull State Park
notes: Location of a Norwegian colony established by renowned violinist Ole Bull

name: Parker Dam State Park
notes: A herd of elk lives in and near the park.[g]

name: Patterson State Park
notes: Day use picnic area on PA 44, surrounded by Susquehannock State Forest

name: Penn-Roosevelt State Park
notes: Once a segregated black Civilian Conservation Corps camp during the Great Depression

name: Pine Grove Furnace State Park
notes: The furnaces at Pine Grove could consume an acre of trees a day.[f][g]

name: Poe Paddy State Park
notes: Noted by anglers for the shadfly hatch that occurs in late spring

name: Poe Valley State Park
notes: Built during the Great Depression by the CCC

name: Point State Park
notes: In downtown Pittsburgh at meeting of three rivers, site of Fort Pitt[g]

name: Presque Isle State Park
notes: The most visited state park in Pennsylvania, on a peninsula in lake with many beaches[d][f][g]

name: Prince Gallitzin State Park
notes: Park named for Demetrius Gallitzin, Russian nobleman turned Roman Catholic priest.

name: Promised Land State Park
notes: Name is an ironic commentary created by immigrant residents, once owned by the Shakers.[f][g]

name: Prompton State Park
notes: Being developed with the help of Friends of Prompton

name: Prouty Place State Park
notes: Day use picnic area on Long Toe Road

name: Pymatuning State Park
notes: This is the largest state park in Pennsylvania, with one of the largest lakes.[f]

name: R. B. Winter State Park
notes: Park has first cement and stone dam ever built by the Civilian Conservation Corps.[g]

name: Raccoon Creek State Park
notes: Park was built by the CCC and WPA as one of five National Park Service Recreation Demonstration Areas in state.[f][g]

name: Ralph Stover State Park
notes: High Rocks portion of the park was donated to Pennsylvania by James Michener in 1956.

name: Ravensburg State Park
notes: Park named for the ravens that flock near the gorge.[g]

name: Reeds Gap State Park
notes: Once a gathering place for the locals to hold picnics and listen to travelling evangelists

name: Ricketts Glen State Park
notes: Known for its many waterfalls, it was slated to become a National Park, but did not due to redirection of funds during World War II.[d][f]

name: Ridley Creek State Park
notes: Adjacent to the John J. Tyler Arboretum[g]

name: Ryerson Station State Park
notes: 52 acre (21 ha) man-made lake, 38 miles (61 km) from next nearest Pennsylvania state park (Hillman)

name: S. B. Elliott State Park
notes: Park named for Simon B. Elliott, a noted Pennsylvania conservationist and legislator.[g]

name: Salt Springs State Park
notes: Park has three waterfalls and its hemlocks are over 500 years old and some of the largest trees in the state.

name: Samuel S. Lewis State Park
notes: Park named for its donor, a Secretary of the Department of Forests and Waters; now popular for star gazing.

name: Sand Bridge State Park
notes: This is the smallest state park in Pennsylvania, a day use picnic area on PA 192.

name: Shawnee State Park
notes: Rental lodge on an island in the lake

name: Shikellamy State Park
notes: Park overlook is at confluence of West Branch and North Branch Susquehanna River, marina added in 1972.

name: Sinnemahoning State Park
notes: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers reservoir is 142 acres (57 ha), park home to rare elk and bald eagle.

name: Sizerville State Park
notes: Park named for the nearby ghost town of Sizerville.

name: Susquehanna State Park
notes: Park operated by the Williamsport/Lycoming Chamber of Commerce, home to paddlewheeler Hiawatha.

name: Susquehannock State Park
notes: Park named for the Susquehannock, whose chief village was nearby.

name: Swatara State Park
notes: Rail trail is on the former Lebanon & Tremont Branch of Philadelphia & Reading Railroad, park being developed.[g]

name: Tobyhanna State Park
notes: Once part of an artillery range for Tobyhanna Army Depot

name: Trough Creek State Park
notes: Bald eagles have migrated here naturally since the early 1990s.[f][g]

name: Tuscarora State Park
notes: The Tuscarora moved to the area after the Tuscarora War in North Carolina, were later forced out by colonial settlement.

name: Tyler State Park
notes: Old original stone dwellings in park are fine examples of early farm dwellings of rural Pennsylvania.

name: Upper Pine Bottom State Park
notes: A roadside park and picnic area for day use only, on PA 44

name: Varden Conservation Area
notes: One of three Conservation Areas, donated by Dr. Mead Shaffer, being developed

name: Warriors Path State Park
notes: Park named for the Great Indian Warpath used by the Iroquois in war raids on the Cherokee and other tribes.

name: Washington Crossing Historic Park
notes: Site of George Washington's crossing of the Delaware River. Transferred from the Historical and Museum Commission in 2016.[12]

name: Whipple Dam State Park
notes: There was a camp for Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, and Campfire Girls on the north side of lake from 1928 to 1941.[g]

name: White Clay Creek Preserve
notes: Park was donated by DuPont to preserve "diverse and unique plant and animal species, and the rich cultural heritage of the area".

name: Worlds End State Park
notes: A "Must See Park" known for trout fishing, white-water kayaking, camping, and hiking on the Loyalsock Trail.[f][g]

name: Yellow Creek State Park
notes: Crossed by the Kittanning Path, a major east-west Native American trail during the 18th century

name: Beavertail State Park
notes: Operational lighthouse, ocean views

name: Blackstone River Bikeway State Park
notes: One leg of the East Coast Greenway

name: Brenton Point State Park
notes: Host site of the Newport Kite Festival

name: Burlingame State Park
notes: Camping and recreation on and around Watchaug Pond

name: Colt State Park
notes: The "Jewel" of the state park system

name: Fishermen's Memorial State Park
notes: Oceanside camping

name: Fort Adams State Park
notes: Site of the Newport Jazz Festival and Newport Folk Festival

name: Fort Wetherill State Park
notes: Sightseeing, scuba diving

name: Goddard Memorial State Park
notes: Golf course, bridle trails, swimming, performing arts center

name: Haines Memorial State Park
notes: Boating access to Narragansett Bay

name: Lincoln Woods State Park
notes: Freshwater beaches on Olney Pond

name: Pulaski State Park
notes: Day use facility in Chepachet, within the George Washington Management Area.

name: Rocky Point State Park
notes: Coastal park on the former site of Rocky Point Park, an amusement park which operated from the 1840s-1995.

name: Snake Den State Park
notes: Undeveloped historic farm property

name: World War II Memorial State Park
notes: Urban park in process of reverting to local oversight

name: Anasazi State Park Museum
notes: Interprets a large Ancestral Puebloan village occupied from AD 1160 to 1235.

name: Antelope Island State Park
notes: Protects Antelope Island, the largest island in the Great Salt Lake and habitat for bison, Pronghorn, and bighorn sheep.

name: Bear Lake State Park
notes: Comprises three units on Bear Lake.

name: Camp Floyd / Stagecoach Inn State Park and Museum
notes: Interprets sites from the time of a massive 1858-1861 U.S. Army camp prompted by fear of the Utah War.

name: Coral Pink Sand Dunes State Park
notes: Preserves the only dune field on the Colorado Plateau, with a unique color caused by iron oxides and minerals in the Navajo sandstone.

name: Dead Horse Point State Park
notes: Showcases views of the Colorado River and Canyonlands National Park from a finger of land once used as a horse corral.

name: Deer Creek State Park
notes: Adjoins the extremely popular 2,965-acre (1,200 ha) Deer Creek Reservoir.

name: East Canyon State Park
notes: Features a reservoir in a canyon first traversed by the Donner Party and soon thereafter by Mormon pioneers.

name: Edge of the Cedars State Park Museum
notes: Interprets an Ancestral Puebloan village occupied from AD 825 to 1125.

name: Escalante Petrified Forest State Park
notes: Features petrified wood and other fossils plus a recreational reservoir.

name: Flight Park State Recreation Area
notes: Offers one of the world's best training sites for hang gliding and parasailing, plus a modelport for radio control aircraft.

name: Fremont Indian State Park and Museum
notes: Preserves rock art and artifacts from the largest Fremont culture village yet discovered.

name: Frontier Homestead State Park Museum
notes: Preserves historic structures and equipment from the 1850s to the 1920s, including Old Iron Town and an extensive collection of horse-drawn vehicles. Formerly called Iron Mission State Park.

name: Goblin Valley State Park
notes: Showcases an unearthly landscape of hoodoos and other rock formations.

name: Goosenecks State Park
notes: Overlooks some dramatic meanders of the San Juan River.

name: Great Salt Lake State Park
notes: Maintains a public boat launch and 320-slip marina on the Great Salt Lake.

name: Green River State Park
notes: Features a shady campground, nine-hole golf course, and float trip launching on the Green River.

name: Gunlock State Park
notes: Adjoins a 266-acre (108 ha) reservoir.

name: Historic Union Pacific Rail Trail State Park
notes: Comprises a 28-mile (45 km) rail trail on a route used by the Union Pacific Railroad from 1880 to 1989.

name: Huntington State Park
notes: Features a warm-water reservoir.

name: Hyrum State Park
notes: Surrounds a 450-acre (180 ha) reservoir.

name: Jordan River Off-Highway Vehicle State Recreation Area
notes: Offers four tracks for off highway vehicles along the Jordan River.

name: Jordanelle State Park
notes: Comprises two recreation areas on Jordanelle Reservoir.

name: Kodachrome Basin State Park
notes: Showcases 67 rock spires and other geologic wonders in a basin so photogenic it was named after Kodachrome film.

name: Millsite State Park
notes: Features a reservoir and lands for off highway vehicles and mountain biking.

name: Otter Creek State Park
notes: Features a 3,120-acre (1,260 ha) reservoir, begun in 1897 as one of the earliest dam projects in Utah.

name: Palisade State Park
notes: Features a reservoir and 18-hole golf course on the former site of a private resort founded in the 1860s.

name: Piute State Park
notes: Protects a quiet fishing reservoir on the Sevier River.

name: Quail Creek State Park
notes: Adjoins a 600-acre (240 ha) reservoir surrounded by red rock desert.

name: Red Fleet State Park
notes: Features a 750-acre (300 ha) reservoir and a fossil trackway of dinosaur footprints.

name: Rockport State Park
notes: Features a 1,080-acre (440 ha) reservoir.

name: Sand Hollow State Park
notes: Features a 1,322-acre (535 ha) reservoir and an extensive off highway vehicle recreation area.

name: Scofield State Park
notes: Features a 2,800-acre (1,100 ha) reservoir.

name: Snow Canyon State Park
notes: Showcases a canyon carved out of colorful Navajo sandstone and landforms created by the Santa Clara Volcano.

name: Starvation State Park
notes: Features a 3,495-acre (1,414 ha) reservoir where early settlers once struggled against starvation.

name: Steinaker State Park
notes: Features an 820-acre (330 ha) reservoir.

name: This Is the Place Heritage Park
notes: Interprets Utah's settlement era with a living history village and This Is the Place Monument.

name: Territorial Statehouse State Park Museum
notes: Interprets the capitol of Utah Territory, the state's oldest government building, constructed between 1852 and 1855.

name: Utah Field House of Natural History State Park Museum
notes: Houses a state-owned museum of natural history.

name: Utah Lake State Park
notes: Adjoins Utah Lake, the state's largest body of fresh water.

name: Wasatch Mountain State Park
notes: Features extensive recreational developments, including facilities built for the 2002 Winter Olympics.

name: Willard Bay State Park
notes: Provides water recreation opportunities on a 9,900-acre (4,000 ha) freshwater reservoir on the floodplain of the Great Salt Lake.

name: Yuba State Park
notes: Features a reservoir on the Sevier River.

name: Fort Simcoe State Park

name: Fort Townsend State Park

name: Fort Worden State Park

name: Ginkgo Petrified Forest State Park/Wanapum Recreational Area

name: Park Name
notes: ha

name: Amnicon Falls State Park
notes: Contains a series of waterfalls and a historic covered bridge.[4]

name: Aztalan State Park
notes: Interprets a partially reconstructed Mississippian culture village that flourished 1000–1300 CE. The site is a National Historic Landmark.[5]

name: Belmont Mound State Park
notes: Features a 64-foot (20 m) observation tower atop a 400-foot (120 m) hill. Operated by the Belmont Lions Club.

name: Big Bay State Park
notes: Includes a 1.5-mile (2.4 km) beach on Madeline Island, largest of the Apostle Islands.[6]

name: Big Foot Beach State Park
notes: Offers camping and fishing adjacent to a 100-foot (30 m) beach.[7]

name: Blue Mound State Park
notes: Contains observation towers atop the highest point in southern Wisconsin and the state park system's only swimming pool.[8]

name: Brunet Island State Park
notes: Preserves a 179-acre (72 ha) island and backwater channels popular with canoeists.[9]

name: Buckhorn State Park
notes: Protects a scenic peninsula on a reservoir formed at the confluence of the Wisconsin and Yellow Rivers.[10]

name: Cadiz Springs State Recreation Area
notes: Offers water recreation on two spring-fed reservoirs in the mostly lakeless Driftless Area.[11]

name: Campbellsport Drumlins State Park
notes: A unit of the Ice Age National Scientific Reserve.[12]:2[13]

name: Capital Springs State Recreation Area
notes: Encompasses park properties just south of Madison unified in the centennial year of the state park system. A Native American archaeological site is on the NRHP.[14]

name: Chippewa Moraine State Recreation Area
notes: Interprets varied glacial landforms. The park is a unit of the Ice Age National Scientific Reserve.[15]

name: Copper Culture State Park
notes: Interprets a burial ground used by the Old Copper Culture from 3000–2000 BCE.[16] The site is a National Historic Landmark.

name: Copper Falls State Park
notes: Contains 7.5 miles (12.1 km) of the Bad River, including a 2-mile (3.2 km) gorge with several waterfalls.[17] The park is listed on the NRHP.

name: Council Grounds State Park
notes: Lies on a riverbank where Native Americans were said to have once held councils.[18]

name: Cross Plains State Park
notes: A unit of the Ice Age National Scientific Reserve.[19] Consists of land owned by Dane County, the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources, the National Park Service, and the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.[20]

name: Devil's Lake State Park
notes: Protects a 360-acre (150 ha) endorheic lake in the Baraboo Range, hemmed in by moraines and 500-foot (150 m) quartzite bluffs.[21] The park is a unit of the Ice Age National Scientific Reserve.

name: Fischer Creek State Recreation Area
notes: Preserves a mile of shoreline flanking the mouth of Fischer Creek. Managed by the Manitowoc County Park System.[22]

name: Grand Traverse Island State Park
notes: Protects 5 acres (2.0 ha) of land.[23][13] There is currently a movement for this and surrounding lands to be established as a national lakeshore.[24]

name: Governor Dodge State Park
notes: Preserves Driftless Area topography in memory of Henry Dodge, settler and first governor of the Wisconsin Territory.[25]

name: Governor Nelson State Park
notes: Contains a 500-foot (150 m) beach, restored prairie, and ancient Indian mounds.[26]

name: Governor Thompson State Park
notes: In development around a series of lakes and streams.[27]

name: Harrington Beach State Park
notes: Features a mile-long beach, a white cedar swamp, and a 26-acre (11 ha) quarry lake.[28]

name: Heritage Hill State Historical Park
notes: Comprises an open-air museum of 25 historical structures and over 11,000 artifacts managed by a non-profit organization. Six of the buildings are on the NRHP.[29]

name: High Cliff State Park
notes: Straddles the cliff of the Niagara Escarpment on the northeast shore of Wisconsin's largest lake.[30] A group of effigy mounds is on the NRHP.

name: Hoffman Hills State Recreation Area
notes: Features trails and a 60-foot (18 m) observation tower among hills covered in forest, prairie, and wetlands.[31]

name: Holzhueter Farm Conservation Park
notes: Under development. Managed by Jefferson County, owned by the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources[32][13]

name: Interstate State Park
notes: Preserves a basalt river gorge joinly with an adjacent state park in Minnesota. The park is within the Saint Croix National Scenic Riverway and the Ice Age National Scientific Reserve and contains the western terminus of the Ice Age Trail.[33]

name: Kinnickinnic State Park
notes: Offers boat-in camping and overlooks at the sandy river delta at the mouth of the Kinnickinnic.[34]

name: Kohler-Andrae State Park
notes: Preserves dunes, golden sand beaches, and pine woodland.[35]

name: Lake Kegonsa State Park
notes: Adjoins a 3,209-acre (1,299 ha) glacial lake in rural Dane County.[36]

name: Lake Wissota State Park
notes: Features forest, prairie, and a 285-foot (87 m) swimming beach on a reservoir of the Chippewa River (Wisconsin).[37]

name: Lakeshore State Park
notes: Provides urban green space on Milwaukee's lakefront.[38]

name: Menominee River State Park and Recreation Area
notes: Protects several miles of the Menominee River in conjunction with Michigan's Menominee River State Recreation Area.[39]

name: Merrick State Park
notes: Offers fishing and boating on quiet backwaters of the Mississippi.[40]

name: Mill Bluff State Park
notes: Contains unusual steep sandstone bluffs that formed as islands in Glacial Lake Wisconsin.[41]

name: Mirror Lake State Park
notes: Surrounds a reservoir whose wooded shores and 50-foot (15 m) cliffs often keep the water mirror-smooth.[42] The Seth Peterson Cottage designed by Frank Lloyd Wright is on the NRHP.

name: Natural Bridge State Park
notes: Contains the largest natural arch in the state and an NRHP-listed rock shelter once used by Paleo-Indians.[43]

name: Nelson Dewey State Park
notes: Encompasses a 500-foot (200 m) river bluff that was once part of the estate of Nelson Dewey, Wisconsin's first governor.[44]Stonefield estate is on the NRHP.

name: New Glarus Woods State Park
notes: Preserves mature forest and restored prairie.[45]

name: Newport State Park
notes: Comprises Wisconsin's only wilderness-designated park.[46]

name: Pattison State Park
notes: Contains 165-foot (50 m) Big Manitou Falls, the highest waterfall in Wisconsin and the fourth-highest east of the Rocky Mountains.[47]

name: Peninsula State Park
notes: Contains a golf course, summer theater, group camps, and lighthouse on nearly 7 miles (11 km) of shoreline on the Door Peninsula.[48] The 1868 Eagle Bluff Lighthouse is on the NRHP.

name: Perrot State Park
notes: Features 500-foot-high (200 m) bluffs bearing rare goat prairie communities on their southwestern faces.[49]

name: Potawatomi State Park
notes: Protects steep-to-sheer shoreline on the Door Peninsula.[50]

name: Rib Mountain State Park
notes: Straddles 1,924-foot (586 m) Rib Mountain, one of the highest points in Wisconsin.[51]

name: Richard Bong State Recreation Area
notes: Supports recreational activities, including ATVs, falconry, hunting and sled dog training, and model aircraft on the site of the abortive R.I. Bong Air Force Base.[52]

name: Roche-a-Cri State Park
notes: Contains a 300-foot (91 m) outcropping bearing the NRHP-listed Roche-a-Cri Petroglyphs.[53]

name: Rock Island State Park
notes: Encompasses most of vehicle-free Rock Island, accessed by two ferry rides at the tip of the Door Peninsula. Four listings are on the NRHP, including the 1836 Pottawatomie Lighthouse and inventor Chester Thordarson's 20th-century estate.[54]

name: Rocky Arbor State Park
notes: Preserves sandstone outcroppings similar to the nearby Dells of the Wisconsin River along one of the river's former channels.[55]

name: Straight Lake State Park
notes: In development around a lake surrounded by mature forest and glacial landforms.[56]

name: Tower Hill State Park
notes: Interprets a reconstructed shot tower where lead shot was manufactured 1832–1860.[57] The tower is on the NRHP.

name: Whitefish Dunes State Park
notes: Protects dunes that formed across the mouth of a bay. A district of eight habitation sites dating from 100 BCE to 1800 CE are on the NRHP.[58]

name: Wildcat Mountain State Park
notes: Comprises a steep ridge overlooking the Kickapoo Valley.[59]

name: Willow River State Park
notes: Contains a waterfall in a sandstone gorge and a 172-acre (70 ha) lake.[60]

name: Wyalusing State Park
notes: Occupies a 500-foot-high (150 m) bluff overlooking the confluence of the Wisconsin and Mississippi Rivers.[61] The park's hardwood forest is a National Natural Landmark and a district of prehistoric mounds is on the NRHP.

name: Yellowstone Lake State Park
notes: Surrounds a 455-acre (184 ha) reservoir built in the lake-poor Driftless Area.[62]

name: Bear River State Park
notes: Within the city limits of Evanston

name: Boysen State Park
notes: Surrounds the Boysen Reservoir

name: Buffalo Bill State Park
notes: Surrounds the Buffalo Bill Reservoir

name: Curt Gowdy State Park
notes: Recreation on and around three reservoirs

name: Edness K. Wilkins State Park
notes: On the North Platte River

name: Glendo State Park
notes: Surrounds the Glendo Reservoir

name: Guernsey State Park
notes: Surrounds the Guernsey Reservoir

name: Hawk Springs State Recreation Area
notes: Surrounds the Hawk Springs Reservoir

name: Hot Springs State Park
